raw_text:
Holmes urged to compete at Worlds
 
 Jolanda Ceplak has urged Britain's Kelly Holmes to continue competing at the major championships.
 
 Double Olympic gold medallist Holmes has strongly hinted she will not run in this year's Worlds and is undecided about next month's European Indoors. But World Indoor 800m record holder Ceplak said: "There is never an easy race when she is in the field. There is only excitement at what might happen. "It is good for the sport. She always fetches the best out of everyone." Ceplak has been a great rival of Holmes' during the Briton's career and the pair fell out when Holmes questioned the manner of the Slovenian's runaway 800m victory at the 2002 European Championships. But the controversy has since been forgotten, with Ceplak acting as pacemaker for Holmes' failed attempt on the British Indoor 1500m record at the Norwich Union Grand Prix in Birmingham in 2003.
 
 Ceplak added: "I like running against her - you know the race is always going to be fast. "That is the sort of competition that I like. She is special to me. She was like my idol from the beginning of my career." Meanwhile, Ceplak will be looking to follow up last Saturday's win in Boston with a fast time and victory in Friday's Night of Athletics in Erfurt, Germany. Britain's Jason Gardener had been expected to defend his 60m title in Erfurt but instead he will save himself for a competition in Leipzig on Sunday. Gardener's decision means Scotland's 400m man Ian Mackie will carry British hopes in what looks sure to be a tough preparation for next weekend's Norwich Union European trials in Sheffield.
llama3.2:1b: Kelly Holmes is considering not competing at the World Championships due to her uncertain availability for the European Indoors, but Jolanda Ceplak says she still wants to compete and that running against Holmes would be exciting competition. Ceplak values their rivalry and sees Holmes as a strong competitor. She will look to improve and win in two upcoming events: the Night of Athletics in Erfurt, Germany, and the Norwich Union European trials in Sheffield.
llama3.2:3b: Kelly Holmes has been urged by Jolanda Ceplak to continue competing at major championships, citing the excitement and competitive nature of racing against her. The two former rivals have put aside past controversy, with Ceplak praising Holmes' ability to bring out the best in others. Ceplak will focus on a fast time and victory in Erfurt's Night of Athletics, while Britain's 60m title hopes are now with Ian Mackie.
gemma2:2b: Jolanda Ceplak encourages Kelly Holmes to continue competing, emphasizing the excitement and competitive spirit she brings to races. Ceplak views their rivalry as beneficial for the sport. Jason Gardener will miss the Night of Athletics in Erfurt due to a focus on preparation for the Leipzig competition on Sunday, shifting British hopes to Ian Mackie.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Britain’s Kelly Holmes urged Jolanda Ceplak, the British athlete competing at Worlds, to continue competing and run faster. Ceplak praised Holmes as "superior" and had her 800m world-record time, but declined to compete at Worlds.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Jolanda Ceplak encourages Britain's Kelly Holmes to compete at the World Indoor Championships, citing her as an inspirational rival and suggesting the event could produce exciting results despite its challenging nature. Ceplak will aim for fast times and victory in Friday's Night of Athletics competition.
qwen2.5:3b: Jolanda Ceplak has urged Kelly Holmes to continue competing at major championships despite hints Holmes may not run this year's Worlds or next month’s European Indoors. Ceplak, who was Holmes' rival and pacemaker during her career, praises Holmes’ ability to motivate competitors, though they fell out over a 2002 dispute. Ceplak will compete in the Night of Athletics in Erfurt while Jason Gardener has been expected to defend his title but instead chose to save himself for an upcoming competition, leaving Ian Mackie as Britain’s leading contender for the European trials.
opencoder:1.5b: Holmes urged to compete at Worlds with the confidence of her professional rivals. Jolanda Ceplak, who has been known to have strong support from her close family and friends, expressed her excitement when Holmes persuaded her to continue competing in the major championships. Double Olympic gold medallist Holmes has hinted she will not run this season’s Worlds due to uncertainty about next month’s European Indoors. However, Ceplak said: "There is never an easy race as long as you are consistently in the field. There is only excitement at what might happen. It's a good sport for anyone who wants to test their skills." In addition to this, Ceplak has been a formidable rival of Holmes' during the Briton's career and the pair faced a fair amount of controversy when Holmes questioned the manner of the Slovenian's runaway 800m victory at the 2002 European Championships. However, it has since been forgotten, with Ceplak acting as a pacemaker for Holmes’ failed attempt on the British Indoor 15,000m record at Norwich’s Union Grand Prix in Birmingham last December. As such, Ceplak is known to be a formidable competitor and always fetches the best out of those who are there.
smollm:1.7b: Holmes urged to compete at Worlds

Then I see that Holmes and Ceplak had a history of rivalry before Holmes questioned Ceplak in 2002. They had fallen out, but now it seems forgotten. Ceplak was preparing for a race in Birmingham this year, but Holmes failed to secure that record.

Ceplak is looking to follow up on his Boston win with a fast time and victory in Erfurt next week. He's also planning to defend his 60m title there and save Sunday's competition against Jason Gardener in Leipzig for Ian Mackie in his preparations for the Norwich Union European Trials.

She has been a great rival since 2001, but Holmes questioned her victory in 2002. Ceplak prepared for Birmingham's indoor 1500m record and aims to win Erfurt next week with a fast time. She also intends to defend his Boston 60m title in Erfurt and save Sunday's competition against Jason Gardener for Ian Mackie's Trials in Sheffield.

Holmes is strongly hinted to be uncertain about next month's European Indoor 800m championships due to her ongoing rivalry with Ceppa which was forgotten after their feud in the 2002 European Championships when Holmes questioned the Slovenian's fast pace. However, Ceppa emphasized that there is only excitement for Holmes and the sport of athletics while Holmes is "special" to her. Ceppa will now aim for a fast time and victory in Erfurt on Friday in addition to Leipzig on Sunday where Scotland's Ian Mackie is expected to compete in the 400m event.

Holmes has strongly hinted that she will not compete in this year's Worlds, but World Indoor 800m record holder Ceplak has expressed interest in seeing what unfolds next month. It's a testament to Kelly's potential, and the excitement for future challenges that both competitors have instilled in the sport.
